contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Ivan Niven.jpg|thumb|Ivan Niven]] '''Ivan Morton Niven''' (October 25, 1915 – May 9, 1999) was a [[Canada|Canadian]]-[[USA|American]] [[mathematician]], specializing in [[number theory]]. He was born in [[Vancouver]]. He did his undergraduate studies at the [[University of British Columbia]] and was awarded his doctorate in 1938 from the [[University of Chicago]].<ref>{{MathGenealogy|id=6349}}</ref> He was a member of the [[University of Oregon]] faculty from 1947 to his retirement in 1981. He received the University of Oregon's Charles E. Johnson Award in 1981. Niven completed the solution of most of [[Waring's problem]] in 1944. This problem, based on a 1770 conjecture by [[Edward Waring]], consists of finding the smallest number ''g''(''n'') such that every positive integer is the sum of at most ''g''(''n'') ''n''th powers of positive integers. [[David Hilbert]] had proved the existence of such a ''g''(''n'') in 1909; Niven's work established the value of ''g''(''n'') for all but finitely many values of ''n''. He was president of the [[Mathematical Association of America]] (MAA) from 1983 to 1984.<ref>[http://www.maa.org/history/presidents/niven.html MAA presidents: Ivan Niven]</ref> He received the MAA Distinguished Service Award in 1989. He died in 1999 in [[Eugene, Oregon]]. He was honored by being selected to write the [[Carus Mathematical Monograph|Carus Monograph]] Number 11, entitled ''Irrational Numbers''.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Rosenbaum, R. A.|title=Review: ''Irrational Numbers'' by Ivan Niven. Carus Monograph, no. 11: New York, Wiley, 1956|journal=Bull. Amer. math. Soc.|year=1959|volume=64|issue=2|pages=68–69|url=http://www.ams.org/journals/bull/1958-64-02/S0002-9904-1958-10170-6/S0002-9904-1958-10170-6.pdf}}</ref> [[Niven number]]s, [[Niven's constant]], and [[Niven's theorem]] are named in his honor; also, in 2000, the asteroid [[12513 Niven]], discovered in 1998, was named after him. He has an [[Erdős number]] of 1. ==Popular works by Niven== *(1959) ''Mathematics: A house built on sand?'' *(1960) (with Herbert S.
